page.name: Full Stack Development
page.description: Full Stack Development is the end-to-end development of web applications, where a developer handles the client-side (front-end), server-side (back-end), APIs, databases, and deployment infrastructure. A full stack developer is capable of building an entire functional product from UI to server logic and managing deployment.
page.title: Introduction to the Website Development Course by Rohit Gurkhe

content.warning: Below is a comprehensive explanation of how full-stack relates to advanced CS domains.

text.line: A full-stack application is a distributed, multi-layered software system that integrates user interfaces, business logic, data management, cloud infrastructure, and network communication, requiring knowledge of system architecture, operating systems, security, algorithms, and distributed systems.

text.head: This goes far beyond “frontend + backend” — it is the intersection of numerous advanced computer science fields.

content.note: A full-stack application is commonly described as software that includes both the client-side (frontend) and server-side (backend). However, in advanced computer science, full-stack development extends deeper into system architecture, distributed systems, data management, networks, concurrency, security, and scalability.

text.line: While planning is not just deciding what to make. It is about designing a system, not a 'site.' This includes architecture, workflows, business logic, performance, scalability, and long-term maintainability. Good products come from an aligned relationship between design (how it feels and functions for users) and development (how it is built and behaves in the system).
The philosophy behind the mix can be summarized as design creates clarity for users; development creates clarity for machines. A great product balances both without sacrificing either.

Scalability of Experience and System together is one of the most important principles in modern software development — not just technically, but strategically. Scalability and iteration determine whether your application can survive, grow, and improve over time. They are the foundation of long-lasting, successful software. Scalable architecture is the difference between a hobby project and a real application. Backend scalability means your system can handle more users, more data, higher traffic spikes, more API calls, and more integrations. Without collapsing, slowing down, or requiring a full rebuild.

Scalability and iteration together create sustainable growth because a scalable user experience makes iteration easier, a scalable backend ensures iteration remains safe, and data-driven design evolution naturally adapts system architecture. When the system is modular, the design can expand without breaking existing functionality. Combined, these qualities create a self-improving product that becomes stronger with every update.

content.warning: Although both application and web servers serve content to clients, they operate at different layers, solve different problems, and handle fundamentally different workloads.

text.line: An Application Server is a specialized software framework that provides an environment for running, managing, and scaling server-side application logic. It sits between the web server and the database, hosting the actual business logic that powers dynamic applications. In modern system architecture, an application server is the core execution engine for backend services.

text.head: This goes far beyond “frontend + backend” — it is the intersection of numerous advanced computer science fields.

content.note: The core purpose is designed for intelligent processing, they’re not interchangeable. They serve different constraints than a traditional web server.

text.line: An application server is a runtime environment that provides everything required to execute business logic, handle state, manage resources, and enable scalable interaction between clients, services, and databases. Modern application servers go far beyond simply “running backend code”—they orchestrate entire distributed systems.

Modern  behave like Execution Containers & Managed Runtime for application components, providing thread management & pooling which optimizes CPU usage with worker thread pools. It prevents thread explosion under high load and allows non-blocking I/O or event loops (Node.js, Vert.x).which is tenderly related to memory & object lifecycle management such as automatic object pooling (JMS, DB connections). They offer managed memory zones for session, cache, I/O buffers and Classloading Isolation.

Application servers support different approaches to preserving state with their state management models useful for workflows, transactions, session objects and scale better across distributed clusters. They can be listed as in-memory stateful containers, stateless components, sticky vs non-sticky sessions.

A key responsibility to application servers is resource management & service orchestration which definitely prevents resource starvation and improves throughput but ensures loose coupling: application code doesn’t store config.
Other aspects of application servers that they embed are enterprise-grade advanced security infrastructure, concurrency control, cluster management, observability & runtime introspection, etc.

An application server is a managed execution environment that abstracts concurrency, security, transactions, state, resource pools, messaging, scaling, observability, deployment & clustering. Its primary goal is to let developers focus on business logic while the server handles the system complexity, especially in distributed environments.

content.warning: All three together form the complete client-side of any web application. Not a warning sign — but a reality check for every developer. You must understand all three, because they form the complete browser environment.

text.line: HTML defines the content and structure of a web page. It creates elements like headings, paragraphs, images, forms, buttons, and links. Think of HTML as the skeleton of the website that tells the browser what elements exist.

CSS controls the appearance and layout of the HTML elements. It handles colors, fonts, spacing, alignment, responsiveness, animations, and overall design. CSS makes the website visually appealing and responsive across different devices. It is the skin and clothing of the webpage.

JavaScript adds interactivity and dynamic behavior to the webpage. It handles user actions (clicks, input, scrolling), updates content without page reloads, communicates with servers via APIs, and controls application logic. JavaScript is the brain that makes the page interactive and functional.

content.note: HTML creates the content, CSS styles the content, JavaScript makes the content behave.”That’s the entire web in one step.

text.line: A modern web page can be modeled as a multi-layered, self-mutating hierarchical data structure where each layer interacts like cooperating algorithms. The closest formal data structure to a web page is a dynamically evolving, event-driven, styled DOM tree with auxiliary graphs, caches, and execution contexts. A web page is mutable n-ary tree that supports both read and write operations at runtime.

Each node becomes an HTML element object in Document Object Model (DOM) tree so each node can have attributes, pointers to children, and sibling links. DOM tree supports efficient traversal algorithms (DFS, BFS), mutation operations, etc.

CSS builds a CSS Object Model that forms a separate tree then merges with the DOM. Since cascade and inheritance behave like a priority-resolved dependency graph, specificity uses weighted conflict resolution algorithm and the final style is computed through traversal and rule aggregation. CSS resolution is multilevel priority DAG merged with a tree to compute final layout.

Browser combines DOM and CSSOM to render tree formed as the derived data structure which normally excludes non-visible nodes (e.g., script tags), contains computed styles plus geometry and supports layout algorithms (Flexbox, Grid = constraint solvers). In CS terms, a render tree is also a projection of two trees into a new optimized tree used for painting.

JavaScript runtime turns your page into a reactive system with the event loop acting like a queue for the tasks and  events where all user interactions (click, scroll) form an event graph, triggering callbacks bound to DOM nodes. In DS terms, JS runtime, and also nodes to graph of event sources feeding multiple queues processed by a loop are turned into a single system.

A web page is essentially a dynamic, multi-tier data structure consisting of a mutable DOM n-ary tree, a cascading CSSOM dependency graph, and a derived Render Tree used for layout and painting. JavaScript binds an event-driven execution graph to this structure through queues, microtasks, and callbacks, turning the tree into a reactive system. The browser further maintains layer trees, display lists, and GPU command buffers, making a web page function like a hybrid of hierarchical trees, DAGs, priority queues, and reactive graphs—all continuously updated as the user interacts.

content.warning: You are always free to form a component from any structure. However, here we discuss how to make it using React—but the in-depth details are not covered here.

text.head: React’s “brain” is the Fiber architecture, introduced to make  rendering interruptible, pausable, resumable, and prioritized.

text.line: Key ideas in the Reconciliation & Fiber Architecture show that, React splits rendering into two phases where in render phase work is computed and in the Commit phase DOM is updated. Work can be paused to give priority to urgent tasks like user input. This enables features like concurrent mode, suspense, and smoother ui.

content.note: Some of the topics covered here are how React works internally (Fiber, reconciliation), performance optimizations (memoization, concurrency), modern rendering strategies (Concurrent mode, Suspense, RSC), architecture (hooks-driven, context optimization) and production stability.

text.line: Context optimization and avoiding unnecessary re-renders becomes important in very large components compared to normal ones. Context causes a full re-render of all its consumers whenever the value changes. Techniques to optimize this include splitting contexts, memoizing context values, and using libraries like Jotai, Zustand, or Recoil for granular updates.

In the Virtual DOM, React updates only the nodes that actually changed by comparing two trees. If the element type changes, React fully replaces the old element with the new one. When props or state change, React updates only the affected part of the tree. However, if list keys change, React may re-render more items. Keys are crucial to prevent incorrect reordering and avoid subtle bugs.

To understand React architecture patterns, the Container–Presenter pattern separates logic-heavy components from UI components. In a Hooks-driven architecture, all logic is moved into custom hooks so that components remain pure UI. For state machine integration, libraries like XState are used to handle complex workflows and predictable state transitions.

State Management Patterns arranges React data into proper way to handle interactions with the user entity whereas there can be ways to manage info into react beyond Redux, modern approaches include Zustand, Recoil, Jotai, Redux Toolkit (RTK), etc. with all their indifferent advantages brings into the react lifecycle.

In ways custom renderers & react reconciler work, React isn’t only for the DOM. Custom renderers exist for React Native, React Three Fiber (3D), Ink (CLI apps), React PDF. React DOM is just another renderer.

page.name: Beginner Friendly Cloud Deployment On AWS
page.description: Cloud is defined as public or private platform to let build your applications without managing the underlying infrastructure. While cloud gives you many options as a user to deploy, run your infrastructure and extend your servers in the cloud by managing their existence. There is definitely some ways to find out how to use them. Here's one and I will give you a simple practical guide to deploy your first website on the cloud and understand about solving problems in the way of cloud deployment. Simple solution is to look at it around the dawn. Happy coding!
page.title: How to deploy static and node apps on AWS

content.warning: We will be talking about deploying your first website on the cloud mostly keeping in mind platforms like aws.

text.line: A static site include files that don’t change on the server like index.html, styles.css, app.js, images, etc. You usually build them locally (or with a build step) then upload the output (dist/ or public/) to the host. To walk you through beginner-friendly, step-by-step instructions for deploying a static site to  AWS S3 with CloudFront.

content.note: It also explain the essential concepts used (CDN, DNS, TLS, caching, index.html, etc.) in a straightforward way without cloud vendor details so you learn the ideas, not only the clicks.

text.line: The goal of AWS S3 (static hosting) with CloudFront (CDN) is to upload your static files to an S3 bucket, serve them through CloudFront for global delivery and HTTPS.

Steps in console with CLI options is to prepare your files, always make sure your site has an index.html in the site root. If it’s a single-page app (SPA), also plan a redirect rule to index.html for client-side routing (we’ll show where to set that). Create an S3 bucket in console with open S3 then create bucket, choose a unique bucket name (e.g., my-site-rohit) and select a region. Uncheck “Block all public access” only if you plan to make the bucket public although not recommended long-term. Better to keep bucket private and use CloudFront to access it.
Upload files quick in console, open bucket, upload, drag & drop your site folder (e.g., dist/).

Since --acl public-read makes objects readable to the public. For better security, skip public ACL and use CloudFront with an Origin Access Control (OAC) so the bucket stays private. With Set content types & caching, S3 will often set MIME types automatically, but verify .js, .css, .svg, etc. have correct Content-Type. Set Cache-Control for static assets so CDN caches them.

CloudFront distribution in aws lets you create cloudfront to your origin in your S3 bucket. If your bucket is public, set Origin Access Control (or previously OAI) so CloudFront fetches from a private bucket. This prevents direct access to S3 URLs. Set Default Root Object to index.html. Enable HTTPS (CloudFront provides a default certificate on *.cloudfront.net; you can attach your custom domain certificate later). Configure behavior to forward query strings or headers only if needed. For SPA, enable fallback to index.html on 404s (via Error Pages settings: set 404 to 200 and point to index.html). Allowing your domain in your DNS provider can add a CNAME or ALIAS/ANAME that points your domain (e.g., www.example.com) to the CloudFront distribution domain name. In CloudFront, add your domain and request/attach an SSL certificate (via AWS Certificate Manager in the region us-east-1 for CloudFront). Open the CloudFront URL (or S3 static website URL if you used public site) and confirm the site loads and assets are served with correct headers.

text.head: Concepts with simple explanations to learn once, apply anywhere

text.line: A Index.html / root object lets someone visits https://example.com/ the host returns index.html (the default root document). Static hosts let you set that default root. With CDN (Content Delivery Network) a set of servers around the world that cache and deliver your files from a server physically close to the visitor for faster loading and lower latency. Origin is the place the CDN fetches the original files from (e.g., your S3 bucket or your Netlify storage). The CDN caches those files. A Domain Name System converts example.com to the host address. You add records at your domain registrar to point the name to your host (CNAME, A, ALIAS/ANAME). TLS / HTTPS encrypts traffic. Modern hosts and CDNs provide free TLS certificates automatically (Let’s Encrypt or built-in provider). Always use HTTPS in production.

Caching (Cache-Control) tells browsers and CDNs how long to store a file. e.g. Long cache max-age=31536000, immutable for fingerprinted assets (app.abc123.js). Short or no-cache for HTML if you update it frequently. MIME types / Content-Type tells the browser what kind of file it’s receiving (text/html, text/css, application/javascript), so the browser handles it correctly. SPA routing fallback brings single-page apps use client-side routes (e.g., /profile/123). The server should return index.html for unknown paths so the client app can decide what to render. Origin Access / Private buckets instead of making the storage bucket public, you can keep it private and allow only the CDN to fetch objects more secure. Build step if you use frameworks (React/Vue/Next/Eleventy), a build step compiles source files into static files (dist/) that you upload. Minification & compression minify CSS/JS to reduce size. Enable gzip or brotli compression on the host or CDN for smaller transfers.

content.warning: The main idea is to build a docker image and push to docker hub so that we can deploy on any cloud.

text.line: Containerization is a technology that simplifies application management by enabling consistent environments, making it easier to develop, deploy, and run applications locally and across different systems. Containerization is needed as traditionally, apps failed because of different os environments or missing libraries or wrong versions or “works on my machine” problems. containerization eliminates these issues. Containerization works by Containers run on top of the host OS. They share the os kernel but are isolated and lets a container engine (like docker) manages them.

content.note: Each container includes application code, required libraries & dependencies with configuration files.

text.head: Here we write a dockerfile to pull an image to set it running

text.line: We build out Image and Run locally. But we also need to push to docker hub so we deploy on Cloud Providers.

AWS ECS Fargate lets you define your task definition that tells aws how to run your container while service keeps containers running in Fargate known as serverless containers with load balancer as an option.

Azure pulls your Docker hub image with auto-scale by HTTP requests and make environment into logical grouping of apps. Google Cloud Run gives fully serverless container hosting and autoscaling from 0. Deploy with one command gcloud run deploy

content.warning: Explaining serverless deployment using a task is straightforward; however, it becomes challenging when you try to understand where the execution actually happens.

text.line: What is Serverless? When you have no servers to manage and pay only when your function runs along with automatic scaling according to the traffic spikes. they are best for events, apis, cron jobs, file processing.

content.note: A serverless function has input (event), your code (handler) and output (response).

text.line: Serverless Triggers (Events) with HTTP Trigger as API Gateway calls your function when someone hits a URL. S3 / Blob / Cloud Storage Upload Trigger should upload a file then function runs automatically. Timer/Cron Trigger  runs every minute/hour/day and Pub/Sub Messages functions run when a message is published. Serverless on each cloud platform runs little different. AWS Lambda use handler.js file to attach trigger (HTTP, S3, cron, SNS) while Azure Functions uses function.json to define trigger bindings for inputs/outputs. Google Cloud Functions very similar. One command to deploy (CLI): gcloud functions deploy helloWorld

text.head: One command to deploy (CLI): gcloud functions deploy helloWorld
Example Hello World API (Same logic for all clouds)
Http request triggers function to returns response. No server, no ports, no VM. Cloud auto-scales the function.
